item.title: ‚ÄúColorado voters are already turning out for the Nov. 3...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúColorado voters are already turning out for the Nov. 3 election, with more than 300,000 ballots cast in the first days of early voting this week, officials announced Thursday.

Secretary of State Jena Griswold said 300,795 Coloradans had voted by Wednesday.‚Äù

The Colorado Sun

Colorado voters are already turning out for the Nov. 3 election, with more than 300,000 ballots cast in the first days of early voting this week, officials announced Thursday.

thedenverchannel.com

Over 300,000 ballots cast in Colorado in first days of early voting, officials say

2020 is a year none of us could see coming. But if there was any indicator of change, the new DNA of our elected body was a good sign the status quo was on its way out. In the last few years, we‚Ä¶

item.title: "The coronavirus pandemic has been stressful for all...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"The coronavirus pandemic has been stressful for all Coloradans. And undocumented immigrants in Colorado are facing some unique stressors themselves as they deal with the pandemic ‚Äî severely limited access to health care, looming deportation concerns for them or their families, and the particular difficulty of getting mental health help."

Colorado Public Radio

It‚Äôs a sunny Saturday morning in a Pueblo neighborhood, and the scent of steak and eggs drifts through the air in Ana Agustin‚Äôs home. She‚Äôs making breakfast for her cousins. The women are keeping up their weekly tradition of hanging out on weekends and basking in each other‚Äôs friendship.

cpr.org

Undocumented Immigrants Face Different Pandemic Struggles And A Complicated Web Of Resources

It‚Äôs a sunny Saturday morning in a Pueblo neighborhood, and the scent of steak and eggs drifts through the air in Ana Agustin‚Äôs home. She‚Äôs making breakfast for her cousins. The women are keeping up their weekly tradition of hanging out on weekends and basking in each other‚Äôs friendship.It‚Äôs a sunny Saturday morning in a Pueblo neighborhood, and the scent of steak and eggs drifts through the air in Ana Agustin‚Äôs home. She‚Äôs making breakfast for her cousins. The women are keeping up their weekly tradition of hanging out on weekends and basking in each other‚Äôs friendship.
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúWhile the count held every January is an undercount, it does...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúWhile the count held every January is an undercount, it does indicate trends. The Metro Denver Homeless Initiative, which manages the Point in Time, noted in a recent report that one troubling trend concerns race. Blacks, for example, make up less than 10 percent of Denver‚Äôs total population but a quarter of its homeless population.

‚ÄúThis is the result of systemic oppression and policies which continue to ignore this racial disparity,‚Äù Matthew Meyer, executive director of the Metro Denver Homeless Initiative, said in introducing his group‚Äôs report.‚Äù

Denverite

A patch of grass opposite the City and County Building has become a place to discuss politics, safe outdoor spaces and a tax to raise money to address homelessness

denverite.com

A vigil in the heart of Denver is supposed to draw attention to homelessness ‚Äî and to possible solutions

A patch of grass opposite the City and County Building has become a place to discuss politics, safe outdoor spaces and a tax to raise money to address homelessnessA patch of grass opposite the City and County Building has become a place to discuss politics, safe outdoor spaces and a tax to raise money to address homelessness

item.title: "Denver middle and high schools will continue with virtual...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

"Denver middle and high schools will continue with virtual learning into November, according to an internal district communication obtained by Chalkbeat. The school district had planned to reopen school buildings to middle and high school students on Oct. 21."

The Denver Post

Denver middle and high schools will continue with virtual learning into November.

denverpost.com

Denver Public Schools to delay reopening middle and high schools to in-person learning

Denver middle and high schools will continue with virtual learning into November.Denver middle and high schools will continue with virtual learning into November.

Join us TODAY at 1 PM for our last Bout the Ballot discussion with Robin Kniech, Denver City Council At-Large. We will be talking about Denver's Prop 2B, which would increase sales tax to fund housing and homelessness services. Join us right here on my page & bring your questions!
item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúI think what the report shows is how reliant we are on fines...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúI think what the report shows is how reliant we are on fines and fees, so we can‚Äôt just pull the rug out in our budget,‚Äù Herod added. ‚ÄúBut what we can do is limit its use and be very specific where we believe it will have the public safety effect that we want it to have.‚Äù

Last year the largest depository of justice system fees was the Judicial Stabilization cash fund, which supports court operating costs, judgeships and record sealing. Nearly $32 million went into that fund from civil docket fees and other court charges. The $50 monthly probation fee raised $19.1 million for probation and drug courts."

Colorado Politics

Colorado generated more than $132.8 million in fines and fees from criminal defendants and civil litigants. However, some people involved with justice policy believe that is too high of a

coloradopolitics.com

State took in over $132.8 million in criminal fines and fees in 2019

Colorado generated more than $132.8 million in fines and fees from criminal defendants and civil litigants. However, some people involved with justice policy believe that is too high of aColorado generated more than $132.8 million in fines and fees from criminal defendants and civil litigants. item.title: ‚ÄúGallegos said she had been hoping to announce that seven or...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúGallegos said she had been hoping to announce that seven or eight branches would open within two weeks. Instead, all she could say with certainty on Tuesday is that no branches would be reopening in the next two weeks and no target date for reopening had been set. She said library staff would continue to track data and consult with health officials before deciding on a reopening calendar.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really dependent on the direction the numbers are going,‚Äù she said.‚Äù

Denverite

Once the buildings are reopened, users will have to wear masks and will find sneeze guards at check-out and reference desks.

denverite.com

Denver libraries were going to reopen within weeks, but rising COVID-19 numbers put those plans on ice

Once the buildings are reopened, users will have to wear masks and will find sneeze guards at check-out and reference desks.Once the buildings are reopened, users will have to wear masks and will find sneeze guards at check-out and reference desks.

item.author: Leslie Herod

item.title: ‚ÄúThere was plenty of down-and-dirty fighting over a few of the...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúThere was plenty of down-and-dirty fighting over a few of the proposals that Denver City Council referred to the ballot. This year, Denver voters can decide if they want to ante up for a cleaner environment, as well as tax themselves to provide more help for the homeless. They can give councilmembers more power in this strong-mayor town, and allow them to exercise some of that power virtually. And finally, they‚Äôve got the chance to show the city‚Äôs three-decade-old pit bull ban the door.‚Äù

Denver Westword

Tax hikes and pit bulls are just the start.

westword.com

Here's What Denver Residents Will Be Voting On This Election

Tax hikes and pit bulls are just the start.Tax hikes and pit bulls are just the start.

item.title: ‚ÄúA Denver-based hotline for Coloradans who need rental...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúA Denver-based hotline for Coloradans who need rental assistance and other housing help has doubled its staff and is working with new partners to meet needs created by the pandemic.

‚ÄúOur call volume spiked through the roof in March,‚Äù said Patrick Noonan, who manages the Colorado Housing Connects hotline run by the nonprofit Brothers Redevelopment. The hotline serving the state can be reached at 844-926-6632.‚Äù

Denverite

Calls to a Denver-based hotline for Coloradans who need rental assistance spiked during the pandemic. Now, thanks to a state grant of nearly $1 million, it has more staff and new partners

denverite.com

A hotline that helps Coloradans with housing problems doubles its staff to keep up with the pandemic

Calls to a Denver-based hotline for Coloradans who need rental assistance spiked during the pandemic. Now, thanks to a state grant of nearly $1 million, it has more staff and new partnersCalls to a Denver-based hotline for Coloradans who need rental assistance spiked during the pandemic. Now, thanks to a state grant of nearly $1 million, it has more staff and new partners

item.title: ‚ÄúSome medications are available to reduce the symptoms of...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

‚ÄúSome medications are available to reduce the symptoms of sickle cell disease, but the only cure that‚Äôs approved in the United States is a bone marrow transplant, and there‚Äôs a roughly 5% of dying from treatment complications, said Dr. Chris McKinney, a pediatric hematology oncologist at Children‚Äôs.

Children‚Äôs and other hospitals are participating in a study testing a gene therapy treatment approved in Europe, but otherwise there have been few new options for patients since the first drug to reduce symptoms was approved in the 1990s, he said.‚Äù

The Denver Post

Some medications are available to reduce the symptoms of sickle cell disease, but the only cure that‚Äôs approved in the United States is a bone marrow transplant, and there‚Äôs a roughly 5‚Ä¶

denverpost.com

Children‚Äôs Hospital Colorado raising research funds to find safer treatments for sickle cell disease

item.title: Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have...
item.content:encoded:
Representative Leslie Herod

Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have community support for this work. We all have a story to tell. Our stories are our strength and our voices will be heard.

"Forget political stereotypes: This history-making legislator is unapologetically progressive, is insistent that state government can be bipartisan (even now), and wants to transform the criminal justice system. And that's just the start of her ambitions.‚Äù
